item.title: Ticket #3348 (Admin (Login) Screen Changes) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description: I did and I still think it looks rather... well, unprofessional I guess is the word I'd use. I mean, the login form is so nicely styled with a background image and everything and then there are just two very plain links stuck there at the bottom.

item.title: Ticket #3348 (Admin (Login) Screen Changes) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Replying to Viper007Bond:

​http://wordpress.com/wp-login.php

-1 to this patch. I get where it's coming from (the translations), but putting the links outside the box and leaving them basically unstyled is really ugly IMO. I think a better solution would be to just better style them in the box so that they can easily line wrap and stuff without going all ugly.

I think if you do a hard refresh on that page to pickup the new css it looks a lot nicer.

item.title: Ticket #3348 (Admin (Login) Screen Changes) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Keywords changed

​http://wordpress.com/wp-login.php

-1 to this patch. I get where it's coming from (the translations), but putting the links outside the box and leaving them basically unstyled is really ugly IMO. I think a better solution would be to just better style them in the box so that they can easily line wrap and stuff without going all ugly.

And careful with at least the wp-admin.css patch. If applied, it'll undo at least one recent commit I believe (the height of the submenu in the admin area). It also introduces more validation errors, but there are already others there, so I guess we don't care.

bryanveloso: update your SVN copy next time before making a patch. ;)

item.title: Ticket #3349 (wp-config pickup consistency fixes) updated
item.dc:creator: RuddO
item.description: Type changed

item.title: 2.0.5-phantom-wp-config-consistency.diff attached to Ticket #3349
item.dc:creator: RuddO

item.title: Ticket #3349 (wp-config pickup consistency fixes) created
item.dc:creator: RuddO
item.description:
What this patch does:

  • calls WP's wp-config.php consistently throughout WP (before it was a mixture of ../'s and dirname(FILE)'s)
  • lets anyone use a WordPress tree composed out of symlinks without issues (perfect for those who host hundreds of WPs in a single server for hundreds of customers, and who by any reasons won't use WP-MU)

These fixes work OK on my setup, and should work OK on others' setups. Just tested creating a new blog and it's all good.

item.title: Ticket #3348 (Admin (Login) Screen Changes) created
item.dc:creator: bryanveloso
item.description:
Some changes made to the WP.com login screen that I want put back into core. <ul> on the page has been moved out of the main box for the sake of not breaking during translations. Less CSS too. :]

Diffs are included.

item.title: Ticket #3347 (Changeset 4455 - SELECT FOUND_ROWS() faster than count()?) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Austin Matzko on wp-hackers notes that SQL_CALC_FOUND_ROWS requires MySQL 4.0, while WordPress up 'til now has worked on MySQL 3.23.23

Just as FYI. I'm fine leaving MySQL 3 in the dust. Matt may feel differently.

item.title: Ticket #3347 (Changeset 4455 - SELECT FOUND_ROWS() faster than count()?) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: In my testing, SELECT FOUND_ROWS() is extremely fast, and adding SQL_CALC_FOUND_ROWS to the post query has minimal overhead. Overall, it's faster for me than doing another SELECT FROM. What are your impressions so far?

item.title: Ticket #3345 (Allow author.php to show even if author has 0 posts.) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: would that show author.php for authors who don't exist?

item.title: Ticket #3346 (Allow author.php to show even if author has 0 posts.) created
item.dc:creator: ruckerz
item.description:
Loading /author/username will return a 404 if author has no posts. It is desirable to show something, in my case, author profiles and let author.php decide what to do if the author has 0 posts.

Rewrote handle_404() to...

if ( (0 == count($wp_query->posts)) && (!isset($wp_query->query_varscat?)
$wp_query->query_varscat?== 0) && (!isset($wp_query->query_varsauthor?) $wp_query->query_varsauthor? == 0) && !is_404() && !is_search() && ( $this->did_permalink (!empty($_SERVERQUERY_STRING?) && (false === strpos($_SERVERREQUEST_URI?, '?'))) ) ) {

Note this includes patches from Trac #1969 (Check for category and author page existence) and also solves final comment by _ck_.

item.title: Ticket #3345 (Allow author.php to show even if author has 0 posts.) created
item.dc:creator: ruckerz
item.description:
Loading /author/username will return a 404 if author has no posts. It is desirable to show something, in my case, author profiles and let author.php decide what to do if the author has 0 posts.

Rewrote handle_404() to...

if ( (0 == count($wp_query->posts)) && (!isset($wp_query->query_varscat?)
$wp_query->query_varscat?== 0) && (!isset($wp_query->query_varsauthor?) $wp_query->query_varsauthor? == 0) && !is_404() && !is_search() && ( $this->did_permalink (!empty($_SERVERQUERY_STRING?) && (false === strpos($_SERVERREQUEST_URI?, '?'))) ) ) {

Note this includes patches from Trac #1969 (Check for category and author page existence) and also solves final comment by _ck_.

item.description: Loading /author/username will return a 404 if author has no posts. It is desirable to show something, in my case, author profiles and let author.php decide what to do if the author has 0 posts.

item.title: Ticket #3343 (Delete categories JavaScript error: Object doesn't support this ...) updated
item.dc:creator: dan-daemon
item.description: Version, Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #3343 (Delete categories JavaScript error: Object doesn't support this ...) created
item.dc:creator: dan-daemon
item.description:
When I delete category, software initiates ajax request to the server, then delete item from the table by ajax response, correct? If so, after it I get JavaScript error: Object doesn't support this property or method.

I use IE7 and thought that this bug in JavaScript with new IE release, then I checked it to Firefox and got this JavaScript error after deleting category (copied from JavaScript console):

$(id) has no properties
​http://my.domain.com/wp-includes/js/list-manipulation-js.php?ver=4187

Also, as I can see sometimes when I receive this error I also get this alert box (mostly Firefox):

Are you sure you want to navigate away from this page?
Slow down, I'm still sending your data[[br]] Press OK to continue, or Cancel to stay on the current page.

This bug presents in IE all time, but in firefox only for first deleted item. Then I do not see any errors, deleting goes well.

item.title: Ticket #3339 (Mysql error while editing post) created
item.dc:creator: tassoman
item.description:
You have an error in your SQL syntax. Check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near ')' at line 3

The page is post.php and it happens when editing posts already published.

item.title: Ticket #3306 (saving post takes me to the wrong page) updated
item.dc:creator: lschiere
item.description: Cc changed

item.title: Ticket #3338 (Blog Search: Ignore Soft Hyphens) created
item.dc:creator: transalpin
item.description:
The W3C and the Unicode Consortium say it: For operations such as searching and sorting, the soft hyphen should always be ignored.

To clarify, a search for “wordpress” should return both “WordPress” and “Word­Press”.

Personally, I extensively use the Soft Hyphen character (U+00AD, ­) for posts written in German, unfortunately making the text unsearchable. It just looks better, even for non-justified alignment.

item.title: Ticket #3225 (Export file does not download in FF) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
3225.diff

  1. Pads export file with helpful comments to fix FireFox 2 issue.
  2. Sends ~made-up Content-type: text/wxr+xml to fix Safari Issue.

Works in

  1. FF 2
  2. FF 1.5.0.7
  3. Safari 2.0.4
  4. Opera 9.02
  5. IE 7

Not tested in IE 6

item.title: Ticket #3286 (Handling of escape sequences is muddled and non-compatible) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Oops, trac converts doubled-up single quotes to italics. :-)

item.title: Ticket #3286 (Handling of escape sequences is muddled and non-compatible) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: So escape only single quotes and escape them in the fashion. Also, make sure $wpdb->escape() is used only when escaping on the way to the DB, and use addslashes() when escaping for things like HTML and JS.
